section.title: Flood Hydrograph Modelling
section.para: From the alternative flood estimation approaches introduced in , the methods and models covered in this book of Australian Rainfall and Runoff focus on the event-based simulation approach. On the background of the more general aspects of catchment simulation for design flood estimation covered in , the chapters in this book deal specifically with the models and design inputs required to transform the design rainfall inputs from into design flood hydrographs at catchment locations of interest.

The models typically applied in the event-based simulation approach are distributed in nature; they represent the catchment being modelled by a number of sub-catchments or subareas; the degree of spatial resolution of models may vary from around 10 subareas to hundreds or thousands of grid cells. The flood producing processes are divided into a runoff generation phase, modelled at the sub-catchment or subarea scale, and a hydrograph formation phase, in which the hydrograph contributions from the subareas are routed along the different stream reaches and storages in the catchment to the point of interest. Node-link type runoff routing models are the most common form of these models, where the nodes represent the subareas and the links the routing reaches.

The hydrologic processes involved in the runoff generation phase, described in more detail in , are represented in a highly conceptualised form as loss models, which divide the rainfall inputs into rainfall excess and loss (without modelling what happens with the loss component). As the name implies, the rainfall excess reflects only the surface runoff component that is directly attributable to the event rainfall. The additional component of streamflow originating from recession flows of previous rainfall events or groundwater inflows is referred to as baseflow. This baseflow component is represented in conceptual baseflow models and added to the rainfall excess component either at the sub-catchment scale or, more commonly, as a total baseflow hydrograph at the catchment outlet.

In the hydrograph formation phase, the routing of flood contributions from subareas through the various stream reaches, floodplains and natural or artificial storages is modelled by hydrologic or hydraulic routing models of different complexity.

section.title: Scope
section.para: This book of Australian Rainfall and Runoff provides background information on the most common models currently used for flood hydrograph estimation, and the derivation of design inputs used with these models. It also provides guidance on how these models and design inputs can be applied for flood hydrograph estimation in rural and urban catchments located in different parts of Australia.

As in other books, the guidance provided here should not be interpreted as being prescriptive, as unusual catchment conditions may require special considerations. Importantly, the application of the models and design data for flood hydrograph estimation should be guided by a good understanding of relevant catchment hydrology concepts.

section.title: Book Contents
section.para: This introductory chapter is followed by a chapter that introduces basic modelling concepts applied in event-based simulation of flood hydrographs and the components of a range of currently used modelling systems. The next two chapters then give details of the baseflow models and loss models applied in flood hydrograph estimation. Both chapters are based on research undertaken as part of the AR&R Revision Projects funded by the Federal Department of Climate Change and Energy Efficiency. They first give the background to the selection of the adopted models, then describe the sources of information for the derivation of design values of baseflow and losses, and finally provide guidance for the practical application of baseflow models and loss models.
